1.subquestion: What is the base length of the right triangle formed within the larger triangle?

subanswer.text: The base length of the smaller triangle inside the larger triangle (with legs measuring 3 units each) would also measure 3 units since they share common height at point B which makes them similar triangles hence their corresponding side lengths must be proportional according to similarity theorem or property. So now if you look closely ,you’ll notice how AB=BC too . Thus giving our desired answer as ‘3' unit here !!! That being said though let me add some more context around why I think so – see below ... ... Here comes Geometry related part :- Suppose RT || BC where T lies somewhere else apart from A such that TR=TC i e 'b" Let ST intersect PR again say Q .. Then SQRTABCD  will become PQRS rectangle whose diagonals bisect each other ie & interchange places wrt centre O due symmetry reasons.. Further applying same logic across either direction shows up quite convincingly resulting eventually towards concluding fact stated earlier ^_~ Thereby proving validity against alternate paths taken initially leading back ultimately reinforcing hypothesis posited above !!
